comments.commentBody:
Here is the other Kevin Drum link.

http://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2013/08/lead-crime-racism-black-wh...

Wrong.  Pike (Holden) was a man of dignity whose lawless activities were as nothing compared to those of the depraved Mexicans and dishonorable Americans with whom he ultimately tangled.  Cruz is the stuff that the Holden character would have wiped from his boots.
"Cruz is more like William Holden in The Wild Bunch, firing away to the end with his gang of criminals, knowing he has no chance to win...."

Cruz is more like William Holden in The Wild Bunch, firing away to the end with his gang of criminals, knowing he has no chance to win.

That plays well in Texas. Expect him to get reelected. In the meantime, I hope they get the Cruz Halloween masks ready in time.

The House Weeper standing up for America? More likely he'll continue to lie down while the uncontrolled Teapot train wreck continues attempting to run over the American economy and further destroy American's now tarnished global reputation.

Indeed.  Mr Speaker, I will ask you a very sincere question from the bottom of my heart:  do you even care about America?  If not, then I beg you, please, Mr. Boehner, resign from your position in Congress.  Leave us, leave America alone.
ZHR, great imagery. I can just see Cruz in a top hat, tails and a mustache tying Boehner to the tracks, or is that lady liberty? Where's Dudley Doright when we need him?

Isn't it wonderful when the "Hastert rule" gets over-ruled? The Republicans in the House just voted 144-87 to kill the Senate offered bill, while every Democrat voted for passage.

Speaker Boehner could break the log-jam in the House by embracing democracy and ditching Hastert and just holding "up-or-down" votes at every instance.

Mr Speaker, how about standing up for America!
-
A valuable insight. Internet forums are not the same as a personal debate. People are looking up the "right" answers and come back with propaganda slogans.

This is a very interesting issue that I have been in the midst of for some time. As a volunteer for a group that asks "what really happened at the World Trade Center on 9/11?" the push-back from people who don't want to hear the facts is amazing. Because of the power of 9/11 in the American psyche, trying to change anybody's perspective is virtually impossible. Telling people that over 2,000 verified architects & engineers have signed the Architects & Engineers for 9/11 Truth petition frequently only brings a blank stare.

Actually, in the last few years people are MUCH more willing to listen ... but those that don't want to listen repeat the most extraordinary claims such as "All buildings these days are built with explosives in them!" or "The twin Towers were flimsy buildings that were built by the lowest cost bidder!"

The most effective way to get people to accept new facts, as other commenters here have said, is to ask questions. Frequently, people have to say something out loud for them to actually he what they said. When a concept only circulates in your thoughts then it doesn't seem to be subject to the same critical review as something that is spoken (i.e. the root cause of foot-in-mouth-disease).

That is why inter-personal dialogue is so important.
"...If the House...acts-up again...it will be a perilous undertaking, memories will be revived...they...lose again..." - worth repeating

I have a theory about this.  Mitch McConnell is worried about strong opposition on his right.  He won't have to if his Kentucky electorate is reminded yet again of the excesses of people on his right.  Right now, they have learned the lesson but American voters have notoriously short memories.  Mr. McConnell has a genuine incentive to subtly encourage the Tea Party kooks to try it again in early 2014.  On one more occasion, in an election year not too long before the primary, he can look like the grown-up statesman helping rescue the country from extremists just like whoever is seeking to take his Senate seat.
We need to remove the debt ceiling limits, period. Most of the rest of the world manages without one quite nicely. They authorize payment up front when they authorize programs and pass bills.

Clearly, in simple terms, the Democrats won this round. Obamacare stands firm and was not repealed, delayed, or harmed in any substantive way. That was their cherished wish, an outrageous deal put out by the House GOP and it failed. The other attempts made by them were desperate measures to save face, or pride, or what have you, and those also did not succeed. Amazingly, no remorse detected for the billions they cost the country, or the disgrace they engendered around the world - shame on them!

But it's not over. It was important to extend the debt ceiling through 2014 - but we will have to hang in there until February, another three and a half months, but that is at least better than the six weeks offered - and rejected. So we end this on a positive note, for now. If the House decides to act-up again in February - mid term election year - it will be a perilous undertaking, memories will be revived, and they will lose again. Big time.

Mark;

I consider myself a progressive.

As a progressive, I think that the trillion dollars or so wasted on the Bush-Cheney war in Iraq, the trillion or so dollars of revenue lost due to the Bush tax cuts, and the loss of hundreds of billions of dollars due to the 2008 financial crisis that was caused by deregulation (repeal of Glass-Steagall), lack of regulation of derivatives, and fraudulent mortgages, caused the massive increase in the federal debt in recent years.

As a progressive, I rather like that the government inspects food, reviews drugs for safety, invests in scientific research, helps insure that people who have worked for most of their lives don't spend their senior years in poverty, that children are fed, that people without money get at least some basic medical care, that children are educated, that roads and bridges are maintained, that airplanes are safe, that the environment is protected, that national parks and forests are maintained.

There is almost nothing that the government does that I want it to stop doing. The DEA, NSA, and DOD can be substantially cut.

I think we can do quite well by working to address the costs of medical care. The ACA starts to do that. Health care expenses can moderate and go down in a few years.

By closing some tax loopholes and with some minor tax increases, we can balance our budget in a few years and have a great country.

What we need now is to follow through on the President's statement that this shutdown was unnecessary and should not happen again.  Actions as consequential as shutting down the government and not paying our bills should require a Constitutional majority, that is, a majority in the House, a majority in the Senate, and approval by the President (or larger majorities in the House and Senate if the President vetoes).  That's what majority rule in our democracy requires.  The current situation is the opposite of majority rule, because of a simple flaw: routine government operations (including borrowing to pay our bills) terminate by default, allowing a minority to block historically routine continuing resolutions and raising the debt ceiling.  Congress never intended to "sunset" these routine operations of government.  There is a simple fix for this flaw: reverse the default and undo the implicit "sunset".  For these routine operations of government (upon which world confidence in the United States depends), the law should be that these operations continue absent a Constitutional majority to the contrary.  Of course, no Constitutional majority (House, Senate, and President) would be so foolish as to shutdown the routine operations of government or stop paying our bills, but that's the point.  If that's what the law required, however, then we would no longer have to go through periodic crises when a passionate minority is tempted to use shutdown or default as bargaining levers.

Typical spectacular oversimplification. Greece crashed because it had way too many public servants on perks such as getting extra annual leave if they used computers - a rort not available to the private sector. It was also a national past time to avoid paying taxes, particularly by professionals. The tax system was so poorly regulated and managed that it resulted in a substantial lack of revenue for government activities.
While Americans keep peddling this type of nonsense and putting it down to some misplaced notion of your national bogey, 'socialism', you will not be taken seriously by those of us who live in the real world.

The money is going to the wealthiest, greediest group of Americans ever. Profits up and wages down. And you blame Washington for that?

The dollar is not devalued on the international market, at least not before this temper tantrum by the wingnuts.

The vast majority of the government spending goes back into our economy, but the top dogs are no longer satisfied with a large share; they need a huge share.

Economic mobility is at an all time low in our country. The minimum wage is a disgrace. Imagine having a full-time minimum wage job. You would bring home $14,500. Try living on that.

I'm about to retire. My wife retired a few years ago. We have scrimped, saved and sacrificed for the last thirty-five years. Our hope has been to have a frugal and decent end to a life of hard work. My wife and I are, respectively, from an unbroken lineage that traces itself to early colonists in New England and the Southwest. We were here prior to the immigrants that produced Senators Lee, Cruz, Cornyn, Graham and Labrador. Both of our families have traditionally been members of the party of Lincoln. Our family's deeply believed in Senator Chase's notion of "free labor, free land and free men." Since Nixon, both my wife and I have moved from the Republican to the independent and then to the Democratic column. I note this because of the GOP openly embraced a notion of this country that is frankly at odds with what it traditionally meant to be a Republican. The GOP is no longer the party of LIncoln. Instead it has morphed into the party of Dixiecrats, creationists and the like.

All that we can say is that we are both very happy that our parents did not live to see an America on the verge of becoming a banana republic due to the shenanigans of the GOP.

The Tea Party revolution was heavily funded by business.

They were supported by corporations and rich people who wanted to see taxes shifted even further from businesses and investors, and who wanted government benefits, including things like Medicare and veterans benefits to be slashed.

They did not send these clowns to Washington to saw off the branch the whole economy is sitting upon.

I suspect that even in their highly gerrymandered districts, many TPers in the House, and even some in the Senate, will find that next election there is a tidal wave of business and PAC money crashing down on them.

Perhaps helping to solve the problem might include:
1. Have large corporations PAY TAXES. Verizon made $20 billion in profits and had an effective tax rate of -3.8% Similar for GE with a -20% tax rate along with ConEd and Boeing. Middle class folks pay. Poor people pay, but corporations get corporate welfare while their CEOs whine about $60 K pensions for public employees.
2. Return to the tax codes of the 1960s and earlier. The rich need to pay more. The endless complaining about their tax bills by some are negated by the honesty of Warren Buffett who knows how little most wealthy pay.
3. Hold the line on Social Security and other entitlements for two years and reinstitute the tax to pay for funding SSA.

Popular ideas? No. Sensible and need to be done? Yes?

That's not the real issue. Everyone agrees that our deficit is growing too quickly. The question is how to fix it.

The Republicans want to cut "entitlement" spending without increasing taxes.
The Democrats would like to increase taxes on the wealthy and corporations while reducing defense budgets.

That is the issue.

And he was supposed to do what? Do you know how the law works? Congress has to write up the bills. He either vetoes or signs the bill. He can try to influence but that's it. I think you're one of the people who were all for the Tea Party taking us hostage and you wanted Obama to negotiate with people threatening to crash our economy. And if he did, what then? You're for Election Nullification I bet.

Forget whether the Republicans or Democrats should take the blame. The buck stops with our President. Time and time again he has showed us that he is not capable of being an effective leader when it comes to engaging with Congress on issues that will shape this country for decades. A sitting President should not have allowed the country to come this close to the brink. It is unacceptable. Did he win this battle with TP Republicans? Yes. But what about the bigger picture? We're just kicking the fiscal can down the road. Moreover, not one of the President's priorities in his February State of the Union has been achieved. Not one.

He won the battle. He is losing the war.

I did not think Obama had it in him.  He was complete steel in getting Bin Laden.  Then in practically every negotiation with Republicans, he gave away the store before negotiations began.  Finally he got it.  He finally got how you deal with bullies and the biggest extremists and ideologues in the history of the country.  Isn't it great that we have a President who learned from his rare mistakes.  And look at these results.  A good president will now become a terrific president.  I dare them to try this again on any issue.  The American people may claim they dislike government but they like food safety, airline safety, national parks social security and Medicare.  Oh, yeah, they dislike Obamacare but like the end of pre-existing conditions, no lifetime caps, portability, lower costs, and  coverage until age 26.

The vote in the house was nearly 2 to 1 for; this demonstrates how the whole thing was a phony issue created by loud talking Tea Party liars. There ought to be a law that a vote be held despite the "leadership" on important issues such as this. The Speaker of the House tried to disenfranchise the American voters by not allowing their elected Representatives to vote. It is hard to fathom how this is even legal!

The Democrats have been extending an olive branch since 2009. All it got the President was Republicans spitting in his face. If the Republicans want peace, its up to them to make an effort for a change. Putting the responsibility for this warfare on the Democrats is completely disingenuous.

87 Republicans in the House voted for the bill. We can only wonder how many unnecessary days the government shutdown was extended, when in reality there appear to have been enough Republican votes to pass a Continuing Resolution. And all so we can do this again in a few months?

I've seen no evidence that the Tea Party is interested in 'conserving' anything.  It would be hard to think of a more wasteful way to squander U.S. wealth and credibility than this most recent debacle.

This is exactly right. The democrats and the White House had nothing to actually "win" by any of this. All they got is a return to the state we were in before the budget talks.
There are no winners here, only losers.
The only solace we have is that America could have lost much more.

Clearly the federal govt is not going to change the way they operate. We can't let this scenario recur in February. How about a lawsuit;  "we the people" vs Ted Cruz and his cronies to get back some of the financial damages due to their 15 minutes of fame and put it towards reduction of the federal debt. Even if nothing is recovered they would think twice about a repeat if their personal finances were at risk.
What else can we expect from a man who in his first speech as Speaker thanked his "brother-in-laws and sister-in-laws"? Learn the language before entering public life.

John Boehner should be impeached as he is an ineffective, easily manipulated Speaker who bends to the will of the loud, ignorant tiny fringe minority of his party. His actions all along demonstrated very poor leadership at best and at worst, cowardice. It is the height of hubris that the Republicans held the American people hostage. They need to get down to the business of actually legislating rather than grandstanding for purely political gain. The behavior of the Republicans in all of this mess has been absolutely shameful and a true embarrassment. I hope the voters remember this terrible and completely unnecessary hostage crisis and vote these so called 'representatives' out of office in the next election.

Spikes5: I come from a long line of family farmers. I can tell you those farmers won't forget next year when they go to the ballot box, because they will still be suffering financially because of this.

Everyone who depends on Social Security will be thinking about it too. Because they threatened to put our nation into default, and said no creditors worth paying were due any money until the bondholders were due money in mid-November. Well, millions of Americans who get their Social Security during the first half of November will never forget the anxious weeks of wondering if their November check would come, and worrying over how they would pay for food and housing in November if it didn't.

So I think the Republicans in November 2014 will find out that they hurt themselves along with tens of millions of innocent people.

These Tea Party and conservative Republicans are acting just like the Southerners did before they started the Civil War. And what the Republicans have done is basically declare a political war on the nation. They are evil people.

Then, Mark, you need to instruct all elected members of your Tea Party that dignity, honesty, personal decorum, and respect for the rights of all other human beings are necessary, positive, mature qualities for themselves.

When the elected members of your Tea Party begin to consistently exhibit all of these desirable, positive, qualities themselves . . . well, you see where I'm going here, don't you, Mark?.

"He who is busy rowing has no time to rock the boat" is the first life lesson which all of these rogue social outliers, who serve you in your Tea Party, need to learn. These truculent children, who managed to mutiny against the peace, dignity, and security of We the People of the United States of America and against our constitutional form of government, need to memorize and to internalize this lesson fully.

Then, all of your elected Tea Party members need to be chaperoned by mature, rational, adults, around the clock, until they prove to We the People of the United States of America that they are now mature, rational, and honest enough to effectively perform the important jobs which We the People trusted them to do in our United States Congress.

Otherwise, each one of these rebellious Tea Partiers is to be strictly confined to their own bedrooms, with absolutely no access to the outside world, or to any of their similarly immature, irrational, acting-out, Tea Party gang members.

Let's see you apply tough love where it's most needed, right in your own "family", Mark.

So basically, the Congress and Senate go on holiday and we return after New Year's to same disastrous scenario.  The damage was done a year ago when the Republicans walked us to the brink of default and caused the rest of the world to question the full faith and credit of the US government.  That damage cannot be undone and is only exacerbating with each replay.
